G.L. c. 218, \u00a7 19.proposition: This action is brought in the Worcester District Court pursuant to G.L. c. 218, § 19 and applicable rules of civil procedure.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential lease and tenancy includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment protecting tenants from serious interference by the landlord with the use and enjoyment of their rented premises. See G.L. c. 186, § 14; Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).

Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, every residential lease and tenancy includes an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment protecting tenants from serious interference by the landlord with the use and enjoyment of their rented premises. See G.L. c. 186, § 14; Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely discusses the covenant of quiet enjoyment in Massachusetts residential tenancies and explains that “every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right,” defining quiet enjoyment as freedom from serious interference with the character and value of the premises. It further ties this implied covenant to G.L. c. 186, § 14’s statutory protection against interference with quiet enjoyment. Thus, the case directly supports the proposition that Massachusetts residential leases and tenancies include an implied covenant of quiet enjoyment protecting tenants from serious landlord interference.
Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The phrase ‘quiet enjoyment’ is a familiar term in landlord-tenant law, signifying the tenant’s right to freedom from serious interferences with his tenancy — acts or omissions that ‘impair the character and value of the leased premises.’ … Every tenancy is deemed to entail an implied covenant that the landlord will not disturb this right during the tenancy. … When the Legislature chose the words ‘quiet enjoyment’ … it must have intended to incorporate these cases into the statute.”

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: The conditions at the Premises, specifically the ongoing mouse infestation and contamination of food preparation and storage areas, render the apartment unfit for human habitation and unsafe, in violation of the State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.

105 C.M.R. 410.550.proposition: Under 105 C.M.R. 410.550 and related provisions, an owner must maintain the dwelling free from chronic or persistent infestation of rodents and must take all necessary measures to exterminate such infestation and prevent its recurrence.

105 C.M.R. 410.020.proposition: The infestation of rodents and the presence of mouse droppings in food preparation and storage areas are serious sanitary‑code violations that render an apartment unfit for human habitation and materially impair the value and character of the premises. See 105 C.M.R. 410.550 (rodent infestation); 105 C.M.R. 410.020 (definitions of “unfit for human habitation” and “sanitary”); Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 199–201 (1979).

Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.raw_text: Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 199–201 (1979)
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.proposition: The infestation of rodents and the presence of mouse droppings in food preparation and storage areas are serious sanitary‑code violations that render an apartment unfit for human habitation and materially impair the value and character of the premises. See 105 C.M.R. 410.550 (rodent infestation); 105 C.M.R. 410.020 (definitions of “unfit for human habitation” and “sanitary”); Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. 196, 199–201 (1979).
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with lack of heat and hot water as State Sanitary Code violations constituting a material breach of the implied warranty of habitability and triggering rent abatement. It contains a general statement that a dwelling with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable, but it does not mention rodents, mouse droppings, food preparation or storage areas, or 105 C.M.R. 410.550 specifically. Thus, while it generally ties serious sanitary-code violations to uninhabitability, it does not itself establish that rodent infestation and mouse droppings in food areas are such violations or that they materially impair the value and character of the premises.
Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “‘[T]he essential objective of the leasing transaction is to provide a dwelling suitable for habitation.’ Boston Hous. Auth. v. Hemingway, supra at 196-197. A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. The essential objective of the warranty is to make sure that the tenant receives what she is paying for.” (379 Mass. at 201–202).

Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.raw_text: Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 788–90 (1994)
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.proposition: A landlord’s deliberate failure to correct conditions that are in violation of the State Sanitary Code and that materially impair the character and value of the leased premises constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See Simon v. Solomon, 385 Mass. 91, 102–05 (1982); Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782, 788–90 (1994).
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.support_reasoning: The court holds that a landlord’s failure to correct known sanitary, building, and fire code violations that substantially impair the value of the premises constitutes a violation of G.L. c. 186, §14 (the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment). The opinion emphasizes that a landlord’s omissions, including failure to repair defects after notice, can amount to a breach of quiet enjoyment, and applies that principle to sustained code violations like inadequate heat, hot water, and vermin infestation. This aligns with the proposition that deliberate failure to correct materially impairing State Sanitary Code violations breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. 782,.relevant_excerpt: “Decisions from this court and from the Appeals Court clearly support the imposition of civil liability under § 14 in circumstances like those present in this case. … A landlord’s failure to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14. … Cruz Management had notice of numerous sanitary, building and fire code violations… [and] the failure adequately to correct these violations… would impair substantially the value of the leased premises as a dwelling place… On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown.”

Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.proposition: When a landlord, after receiving notice, fails within a reasonable time to correct conditions that violate the State Sanitary Code and materially interfere with the tenant’s use of the premises, the landlord has “directly or indirectly” interfered with the tenant’s quiet enjoyment within the meaning of G.L. c. 186, § 14. See Al‑Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847, 850–52 (1997); Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas, 417 Mass. at 788–90.
Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses the standard for liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14 and expressly relies on Cruz and similar cases to state that a landlord’s negligent failure to repair defects after notice constitutes an actionable interference with quiet enjoyment. At 850–51, the court reiterates that a landlord’s failure to repair defects of which he has notice has ‘frequently’ been deemed to violate § 14 and clarifies that liability requires at least negligent conduct, such as failing to take appropriate corrective measures after notice. This aligns with the proposition that a landlord’s failure, after notice, to timely correct sanitary code–violating conditions that materially interfere with use is a ‘direct or indirect’ interference with quiet enjoyment.
Al\u2011Ziab v. Mourgis, 424 Mass. 847,.relevant_excerpt: “Twelve years later, in Cruz Mgt. Co. v. Thomas, supra, we rejected a claim that a violation of G. L. c. 186, § 14, could be imposed only if it were proved that a landlord was reckless… and we concluded that negligent conduct, conduct involving ‘some degree of fault,’ by a landlord could support the imposition of liability under § 14. Id. at 789. We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ … Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord…”

Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.raw_text: Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284–86 (1994)
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.proposition: Defendant’s conduct was not an isolated act of negligence, but rather a continuing failure to act over the course of months, after repeated notice, and in the face of ongoing, obvious, unsanitary, and unsafe conditions. See Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass. 273, 284–86 (1994) (repeated failure to act after notice supports liability under G.L. c. 186, § 14).
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly holds that a landlord’s repeated failure over time to take available measures, after notice, to address ongoing unlawful and dangerous conditions in common areas can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. The court emphasizes that liability may arise from what the landlord "failed to do" or "permitted to be done" and remands for fact-finding on whether the authority stood idle despite continuing complaints and obvious serious interference with tenants’ use of the premises. This directly supports the proposition that a continuing failure to act after repeated notice can ground liability under § 14, rather than requiring an isolated affirmative act.
Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth., 417 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy… In analyzing whether there is a breach of the covenant, we examine the landlord’s conduct and not his intentions… a landlord may not intend to violate a tenant’s right to quiet enjoyment, but may do so nevertheless when the breach is a ‘natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.’ … if the defendant has failed to take any measures… then the defendant may be liable for a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 717\.proposition: The presence of rodents and droppings in the kitchen interfered with the basic residential purposes of the tenancy, including the safe preparation and consumption of food, storage of groceries, and use of the kitchen as an ordinary and essential part of the dwelling. See Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 717–19 (1977) (interference with normal residential use constitutes breach of quiet enjoyment).
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 717\.support_reasoning: The case does stand for the general rule that substantial interference with normal residential use can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment and constructive eviction. However, Blackett v. Olanoff involves noise from a nearby lounge, not conditions such as rodents, droppings, or unsanitary kitchens, and it nowhere discusses food preparation, storage, or kitchen use. Citing this case specifically for the proposition about rodents and droppings interfering with kitchen use misstates its content, even though its broader principle about interference with residential use is consistent in a more abstract sense.
Blackett v. Olanoff, 371 Mass. 714, 717\.relevant_excerpt: "The defendant in each of these consolidated actions for rent successfully raised constructive eviction as a defense... The judge found that the tenants were 'very substantially deprived' of quiet enjoyment of their leased premises 'for a substantial time'... [and] that the tenants’ implied warranty of quiet enjoyment was violated by late evening and early morning music and disturbances... Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did... they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable."

McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.raw_text: McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304, 308–09 (1977)
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.proposition: The State Sanitary Code violations at the Premises, including chronic rodent infestation, are evidence of the uninhabitable condition of the apartment and support Plaintiff’s claim for breach of quiet enjoyment. See Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson, 379 Mass. at 199–201; McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304, 308–09 (1977).
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.support_reasoning: McKenna concerns breach of the implied warranty of habitability and how to calculate damages based on State Sanitary Code violations. It does not discuss or apply G.L. c. 186, §14 or the doctrine of breach of quiet enjoyment, nor does it specifically address rodent infestation or treat code violations as evidence of a breach of quiet enjoyment. The case supports using code violations to show uninhabitability and reduce rent, but not the distinct quiet enjoyment claim asserted in the proposition.
McKenna v. Begin, 5 Mass. App. Ct. 304,.relevant_excerpt:
“On remand, the judge found that McKenna’s tenancy started in June, 1972… Because he found that the major defects for which he awarded damages existed at the outset of the tenancy, he computed damages from that date… 

We also agree with the judge that McKenna is not entitled to receive damages for the minor code violations in this case… In all cases, however, the trial court is given broad discretion to determine whether defects constitute material breaches of the warranty of habitability… To fashion a measure of damages which more closely reflects the actual injury suffered by McKenna we adopt a percentage reduction of use approach…”}

Hemingway v. Bradshaw, 364 Mass. 239, 24.proposition: Defendant’s failure to maintain the Premises in compliance with the State Sanitary Code also constitutes a breach of the implied warranty of habitability, which, while not separately pleaded here, demonstrates the seriousness of the conditions and further supports the conclusion that Defendant’s conduct substantially interfered with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment. See Hemingway v. Bradshaw, 364 Mass. 239, 242–45 (1973); Berman & Sons, 379 Mass. at 199–201.
Hemingway v. Bradshaw, 364 Mass. 239, 24.support_reasoning: This opinion is a criminal case about impeachment with statements taken in violation of Miranda and does not concern landlord-tenant law, the State Sanitary Code, implied warranty of habitability, or interference with quiet enjoyment. The cited pages (242–45) discuss voluntariness of custodial statements and constitutional protections in criminal procedure, not housing conditions or landlord obligations. Therefore, it does not support the proposition regarding breach of the implied warranty of habitability or interference with quiet enjoyment.
Hemingway v. Bradshaw, 364 Mass. 239, 24.relevant_excerpt: We stand by our considered statement in Commonwealth v. Kleciak, 350 Mass. 679, 690 (1966): “We believe that an involuntary confession does not become any more trustworthy, nor do the methods used to procure it obtain greater standing, because the confession is used to impeach the credibility of the defendant rather, than as substantive evidence.” We assume without deciding that in the circumstances of this case we would not for this purpose distinguish involuntary admissions or involuntary exculpatory statements from involuntary confessions.
